Sorry, overlooked your last point about speciation.
That is a good point, t=
hat perhaps the fitness of the individuals is
not as important as that of t=
he overall species, since that will
determine the amount of offspring a par=
ticular species gets.

So the bias then is to genotypic lines that have pro=
duced novelty in
the past, which might be a good indicator of novelty in th=
e future.
Maybe there is a way to reward species in a more principled/expli=
cit
manner? 

Joel

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "joel278" <lehman.154@...>=
 wrote:
>
> Peter,
> 
> That is a surprising result. It seems like never ch=
anging the novelty
> scores would create attractors around old behaviors in=
stead of new
ones. 
> 
> For example, imagine an individual that reaches a =
new area in
> behavioral space. It is assigned a high novelty score. Severa=
l new
> individuals arrive in the same area, and get lower novelty scores (=
the
> first one maintains its high score). What we want is to explore the
>=
 individuals on the 'fringe' of this new area, in hopes of finding
> furthe=
r areas of novetly. However, with constant novelty scores, the
> bias will =
be to investigate the area in the proximity of the first
> individual, even=
 though the ones on the fringe may be more promising.
> 
> If you consisten=
tly get better performance with constant novelty
> scores over a variety of=
 maps perhaps it is worth looking into more.
> 
> Joel
> 
> --- In neat@yah=
oogroups.com, "petar_chervenski" <petar_chervenski@>
> wrote:
> >
> > Hi Jo=
el,
> > 
> > Novelty search is one really inspiring idea. 
> > It is intere=
sting to note that when I added the dynamic adjustment of 
> > the sparsene=
ss/novelty score, the performance was actually worse than 
> > without adju=
sting the novelty score, i.e. an individual always stays 
> > with the nove=
lty score it was born with. 
> > I hypothesize that this is because it enco=
urages such species that 
> > produce more novel behaviors frequently. But =
I guess that the best 
> > way is to recompute the novelty scores at regula=
r intervals.. 
> > 
> > Peter
> > 
> > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "joel27=
8" <lehman.154@> wrote:
> > >
> > > Hi Peter,
> > > 
> > > Glad to hear tha=
t you are interested in the method, and that you've
> > > been able to impl=
ement it.
> > > 
> > > You are correct, the novelty of each individual is c=
alculated with
> > > respect to the current population and the archive.
> >=
 > 
> > > Yes, sparseness in the behavioral space around an individual is
>=
 > > equated with novelty, which is used for the fitness of the 
> > indivi=
dual.
> > > 
> > > Ideally, novelty would recomputed for each individual in=
 the current
> > > generation after each evaluation. In our implementation =
it is 
> > allowed
> > > to get stale for a few evaluations (in the same fr=
equency that
> > > individuals are respeciated according to rtNEAT). In our=
 
> > experiments,
> > > allowing for a bit staleness did not effect the re=
sults.
> > > 
> > > Actually, in the scenario you describe, each of the ind=
ividuals 
> > would
> > > now have a lower novelty, the original individual=
 included. This
> > > reflects that the area around these individuals in be=
havior space is
> > > more dense than it previously was. As more individual=
s come into a
> > > particular area, the novelty of all of them drops, and =
provides
> > > pressure for individuals to do something new in order to be =
seen as 
> > novel.
> > > 
> > > Let me know if you have any more implement=
ation questions, I'll be
> > > releasing my source based off the rtNEAT pac=
kage in the next few 
> > weeks.
> > > 
> > > Joel 
> > > 
> > > --- In nea=
t@yahoogroups.com, "petar_chervenski" <petar_chervenski@>
> > > wrote:
> > =
> >
> > > > Hello,
> > > > 
> > > > I implemented novelty search and the ma=
ze navigation task (it 
> > > > works! :)), but I need to ask you about som=
ething. 
> > > > 
> > > > So when a new individual is spawned from the popu=
lation, its 
> > novelty is 
> > > > computed based on the domain-specific =
distance measure to all 
> > other 
> > > > behaviors in the population and=
 the archive, right. 
> > > > 
> > > > But what about the population itself=
, should every individual 
> > there 
> > > > recompute its sparseness on e=
very evaluation, based on the new 
> > > > circumstances? 
> > > > 
> > > >=
 I ask this because when I observe the sparseness (I assume 
> > sparseness=
 
> > > > equals fitness) of the individuals, say one happens to be in a 
>=
 > very 
> > > > sparse area so it receives a high fitness score. But then =
a 
> > couple of 
> > > > other individuals come into this area, so it beco=
mes more dense. 
> > But 
> > > > that first individual still has a high fi=
tness score? Is this 
> > right? 
> > > > 
> > > > Peter
> > > >
